Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2014 06:32AM bettysgirl wrote: the very thought of chemo is scary- and i don't think that there is anyone here who wanted to do it. I understand your reluctance. I agree you need to talk with the onco and look at all the suggestions. I am not going to lie. Chemo is tough and there are some really bad days. But I was fortunate enough to be able to work throughout chemo with about three days off after each tx. You manage the side effects as they come, you come here and vent and find answers and then you take each day at a time. You will find out that your inner strength will rise up and you will surprise yourself as to how tough a cookie you really are. Best wishes as you move forward.
Posts.Title: No good news here either pugsnotdrugs Hopeful82014

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 04:20AM bettysgirl wrote: all of us at one time had a great fear of the chemo before we got there. Most of my worst fears have not been realized. It isn't fun...but it is something that you can do and get through with a good support system. I have worked through all of mine. I ws out a few days after each tx and have missed more days since i started the taxotere but i am still there. I have been lucky that they are flexible and understand that i am a little more tired some days an i have been allowed to come in later. You have to make the decision yourself but the nausea meds are good, my onco is good about not wanting the se's to deter my life too much and he is very helpful with that. I wish you the best of luck in whatever you decide to do
Posts.Title: Chemo pinkhd pinkhd

Posts.Content: bettysgirl wrote: Took a long time to past first post cuz i don't know all the abbr. and am not a big tech person with posts. I was DX on 6-20-08, sent. node biopsy two weeks ago ( 2 pos nodes) and double MX last Wednesday. I have Invasive ductal but the lobular features of the cancer allowed the thing to hide. I have had mams and tests yearly..biopsy w/marker clip two years ago ( fibrocystic not cancer) this was new spot and didn't see extent until bilat MRI. After surgery path shows 5.5 cm tumor. Grade III they took 10 additional nodes during surgery and no more pos. nodes were found. Clear margins.. Now we wait for this dang fluid to go down, get these aggravating drains out and have the port out in to start chemo as soon as i have healed. I am trying to take it a day at a time, have a good support team and am trying to be thankful that things could be worse and even though i have alot of fluid. I am glad to be past surgery, ( at least i am not waiting anymore) and I decided to do the other side because i NEVER wanted to go through this with the other side if lobular features will let it hide like that..They looked good at the films from the the past two years..it just was a sneaky sucker. Dx 6/20/2008, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/13 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 7/16/2008 Lymph node removal: Right, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Chemotherapy 9/18/2008 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Ellence (epirubicin), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxotere (docetaxel) Hormonal Therapy 4/15/2009 Radiation Therapy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: newbie here bettysgirl Dee42

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2009 04:52AM bettysgirl wrote: Mine was not sterotactic so i cannot speak for that. I did have a clip put in and it did take a while for the discomfort to ease. PCP told me it was kind of like a pacemaker or other device, the body has some adjusting to do. I had lots of trouble with my shoulders after the rads because of positioning..and still do some days. I take advils or other anti-inflammatory for that. Of course when I complained the rad tech asked me if i knew I had shoulder problems before the rads..ahhhh NOPE!!! I hope that the shoulder discomfort will ease for her. If not she needs to find a doc that will listen.
Posts.Title: titanium clip in breast.... Veryhopeful Sallye

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 11:35AM bettysgirl wrote: i'm having the problem now so i can only know it will get worse as the treatments continue. I am also doing heavy lotion and socks and it helps a little. If you find something let me know
Posts.Title: Painful feet and cracking skin after finishing chemotherapy bonbon6565 bettysgirl

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2009 05:58PM bettysgirl wrote: i was where you are at after my first taxotere..i was SO sick. They lessened the second dose and things were better. Sometimes you have to go back for fluids or steroids after the txs to resolve some of the SE's...some of us suffer more than others and i don't know why BUT the bottom line is that while you are miserable right now it will get better, and you can do this. We are all pulling for ya.
Posts.Title: Stopping chemo chico1 vstadey2

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2008 07:08AM bettysgirl wrote: Thanks for your comments. I guess you could say i am a little on the tough side...just know that i cannot change the outcome by crying in a corner and those crying fits always give me a headache so why bother??? I'd rather not be here but i wasn't given a choice. I have a great circle around me filled with women who have walked where i am now walking and while our stories are all different, we all can help each other in some way. The computer i am on is soooo old i pray it will last for a post or two as our laptop died about the time i was dx and it is an expense we dont' need right now. I'm not sure why some of these tumors hide and THAT is the really frustrating part when you do everything right and STILL it does no good...How long do you think it will be before they do the minor surgery to install my port??

Posts.Title: newbie here bettysgirl Dee42

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2013 06:25AM bettysgirl wrote: I had my mamo done right before we were scheduled for a vacation. The clinic and my gyno's office really wanted me to go to the surgeon for biopsy the following week...I told them that if it turned out to be anything I would not get a vacation so I was going...good thing I did. You have to do what is right for you.If it will cause you excess stress to wait then do it now..The whole waiting game is hard but as my dr told me...a few weeks sure didn't make a difference in the outcome. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Biopsy before or after the holiday? birad 4b, scared naturegirl11 Nora5

Posts.Content: May 24, 2009 08:12AM bettysgirl wrote: the surgery is not bad, you are just a tad sore after. The anesthesia is lighter than for a bigger surgery and i was awake quickly afterwards. Some people don't like the port, or say it bothers them. Mine has never given me any trouble and it is SO easy to access for the chemo. I am glad I got mine. If your veins are not good you will be glad to have one too. It will be fine. Take care Bettysgirl/ Lisa

Posts.Title: Dx official yesterday, Concerned with pathology comments KimmyD78 bettysgirl

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2014 04:19PM bettysgirl wrote: I also got the call at work (on a friday) I told my husband first, then the children and only told my boss because she was going to be out of town the next week and needed to know I would be out for further tests, the other co-workers were not told. I asked my husband and children not to tell ANYONE else at that time because I wanted the weekend to myself to BEGIN to process what i was hearing. I wanted to be able to have a little breathing room because in the small town we live in news travels like fire..It was a good thing to be able to focus on me and my immediate household before anyone else was told and I told them on my own terms. You have to do what is right for you.

Posts.Title: Got Diagnosis today ginnysue Harley44

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2009 05:39PM bettysgirl wrote: i was about three weeks out of fec+ taxotere chemo, had 28 rads and finished this past Friday. Am on BP meds, and so far no big fatigue issues. I am a little tired today BUT have been outside more in the beautiful weather, I had more fatigue on the taxotere than anything. I guess after feeling that bad any fatigue would be easier than that. I do notice that bedtime comes a little eariler for me than it used to. I still get tired around 4-5 but that's been going on for years. I will start tamoxifen Monday as onco wanted me to wait until rads were over. We'll see what that does.
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 08:16PM bettysgirl wrote: karen- what you are feeling is what we all felt in the beginning. The waiting is so hard, but as they said above, waiting won't put you in dire jeopardy. You have time to make informed decisions and i suggest just that. Don't rush into surgery unless you know all the facts, and are comfortable with the decision you make.I didn't want to wait either but the CT, PET and other tests gave us more info and i went into surgery knowing it was going to be a mastectomy, if we had not waited for the MRI i sould have been surprised as the mamogram didn't tell the whole story. Take a deep breath( and a Xanex) and know that there is a lot of support here. As far as nodes you won't know that until they do a sentinal node biopsy/ and or surgery. My SNB was a week and a half before my surgery. Just hang in there and know we are thinking about you.
Posts.Title: How long between diagnosis and surgery or treatment? Anxiousmama katiec

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2014 09:32PM bettysgirl wrote: funclassygal-I know this is an amazingly stressful time. I found that the initial time between dx and treatment/surgery began to be the most stressful time of the whole thing. Waiting on results, anticipating outcomes, reading too much...I did have MRI and PET prior to surgery so i know what you are talking about when you say you feel like a pin cushion. Hang in there. You will find your strength. You have to allow yourself to walk through the emotions, have a grumpy cat kind of day and them move on to the next hurdle. I am glad to see that you are here. You will get great advice here from oldies and newbies alike.  I found chemo to be quite doable and never got sick and worked throughout the process. That doesn't mean there were not tough days, but you seem to be able to move forward and go on to the next hurdle. I had read all about the side effects of chemo and was also terrified. I guess i had made is seem so horrible that is wasn't as bad a i anticipated. rads were not too bad for me either. I had no fatigue, went everyday at 4 and did not have a breakdown of skin until the last two weeks. I found a great chemo group here on BCO and we have been close ever since. I do not come here as often as i used to but i pop in from time to time. Know that you are on our hearts and minds and in our prayers. You will sail through this and have a story to share. I wish you all the best in the road that is ahead for you. Love and hugs

BUT whatever the case you need to realize that you are doing this for YOU! You need to fight for YOU and if he cannot support you find someone who can. You cannot give up just because he isn't being supportive. You have a lot to give and giving up isn't the answer. All of us here have been through tough times and please know that we are here to talk to. I'm sure lots of us have had times where we thought about giving up heck it would be easier than fighting but who wants the cancer to win?? It will get better.

Posts.Title: clean PET MissMyrtle bettysgirl

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2010 10:59AM bettysgirl wrote: i am sure you are worrying and with family history it is good to be cautious. You have to be your own advocate in today's heatlhcare and sometimes fight the insurance co for something you believe in. Get the mamo, or ultrasound whatever they need to do to image it. Mine didn't show up on a mamo well but was seen with US and MRI. I highly doubt they will dismiss you because of the history but if you are not happy with the doctor by all means look for another. My prayers are for benign results for you and mom and I apprecaite the sacrifices you are making to allow your spouse to protect us. Being home and being mom and dad both is a hard job and my hat is off to you. Best wishes

Like the others said, you can baby them like i did and sometimes they come off sometimes they dont'. Hope yours dont. Onco told meto take b vits for the neuropathy and it has helped a lot.
Posts.Title: Finger/fingernail problems? How common? Texas357 Texas357

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 05:38PM bettysgirl wrote: Cathie- for me i was tired and the evenings seemed to be long. I go to bed earlier than i used to but the fatigue i had with the taxotere was so bad that any fatigue i had with rads was so much better i just didn't mind it as bad. I had some days where it seemed to catch up on me ( seems like i was always sunday afternoon. after church and lunch i would curl up at about 2 or three and wake up around 6 or 7 and then sleep all night too. Everybody is different and while it is frustrating..just know that it will pass, you will feel better and brighter days are coming your way... Take care

Posts.Title: Any Chemo Ladies starting in Sept 08 MaggieMaeB Emily2008

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 05:37AM bettysgirl wrote: what you are feeling is sooo common for the early days after dx. I was a mess until we started "doing" something. I was also a DD and it is an adjustment to have them gone. Immediatly I was aware that weight was gone. (7 lbs) Some days I am fine with it and some days I am saddened by the change in my shape. It is a long story but the only recon option i was given was the shoulder flap and that wrote any idea on recon off for me. I go flat. I have not worn nor been fitted for a prosthesis. I wear layered shirts. It is a big decision and one that you have to be comfortable with. I knew that i never wanted to have to go thorugh that dx phase again with the other side and with the history of all the fibrocystic cysts it would have been a possibility. Of course you have to know that on the elective side (in my case) they do not take as much tissue and thus there is breast tissue left for a chance of recurrence... I am sorry you are having to go through this. I also hate BC. It is something I wish no woman ever had to go through. BUT we are strong women and when the chips are down we all seem to make it through the tough days and move ahead. Keep coming here for support. I wish you the best..
Posts.Title: bioposy results question marlie67 deborah48

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2009 06:32PM bettysgirl wrote: a good friend of mine was diagnosed over 12 yrs ago with BC with namy nodes involved. She was not given a happy prognosis in the beginning and she is winning every day. She is amazing!!! It can be done.
Posts.Title: 23 nodes removed - all positive joannnc Beverly11

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2010 08:02PM bettysgirl wrote: skd- it will begin as strands coming out then more. i washed my hair and loads came off and it was then that i knew it was time to shave it myself. it does itch when it sheds and my head still was a little achy after i shaved..My hair started to grow back while i was on the taxotere. once it starts to come back it grows about as fast as your hair did before. Mine came back curly  but the chemo curls didn't last too long. it is now straight and the same color as before just not as much texture..FEC wasn't so bad for me. I didn't have taste issues like some do and i was able to work all through chemo. I know you will do great too and i wish you all the best!
Posts.Title: Anyone having FEC? ducky1 SKD

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2010 10:08PM bettysgirl wrote: i also had 3 FEC and 3 taxotere- i was also given emend, compazine and zofran for nausea.. they labeled the 1,2,3 and only once did i go through all three. I will echo what was said before stay ahead of any nausea you do get. Fluids are key. Drink while you are being infused. The more liquids the faster your system can get the meds working and flushed through your system. You will have to see what tastes good to you, somethings you liked won't be appealing. Someone told me to get lemonheads candy if you get the metallic taste but i was lucky and did not get that. The biggest complaint i had on taxotere was that eveything tasted like cardboard. I was able to work all through chemo with a few days out after each treatment. And my hair did fall out on about day 15...BUT it will be over before you know it and you will be on the road with NED. There will be some unpleasant days but you WILL come out on the other side and you will know that you gave the BC the big guns and survived it. I wish you all the best. Lisa
Posts.Title: anyone have FEC-T chemo rackie carofin

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2019 02:47PM bettysgirl wrote: You came to the right place and will find lots of info and support here. Wishing you the best as you wait for test results. Best wishes to you!
Posts.Title: I'd like to introduce myself. HappyAnyway HappyAnyway

Posts.Content: May 11, 2012 01:21AM bettysgirl wrote: yep breast surgeon first. Once you find out the specifics of the pathology then you can go from there. I will also ditto what was said about taking another set of ears..you don't hear it all and another set of eyes and ears are key to the entire journey. This website is also wonderful for searching info. I know the gut reaction is to have surgery fast & first..Hopefully yours is small and early. Mine was a larger tumor and I did surgery first..if i had to choose again i can see the benefit of chemo first (if needed at all) because you know how well the cancer responds to that particular treatment. Before surgery if you are going to have any recon work you need to consult with a plastic surgeon prior to surgery for advice. You probably won't get the referral to the rads oncologist until you have completed surgery. I wish you the best of luck as you move forward. Take things a day at a time. If you have questions, come here and someone almost always has an answer. And with the vast group of women and time zones there is almost always someone online. Good Luck to you!
Posts.Title: Which doctors do I need to see now that I've been diagnosed? 25weeks lago

Posts.Content: May 9, 2010 12:55AM bettysgirl wrote: i too am sorry you had to join us. I think all of us had the gut reaction to just get it out. In my case the MRI was totally important as it showed the true size of my tumor. They did my Sentinal node biopsy first to see if there was node involvement. Once we knew there was I was the one that asked for a PET scan prior to surgery because i had been a smoker for so long. Looking back i can see where chemo first is a good option because you know it is working on your tumor. Some people want to know everything and some don't. I read a lot of books, studied online but the most important and helpful info came from other survivors themselves. Talk to someone you know personally that has had surgery and been through the journey. Talk to the ladies on here. You need time to think through all your options. One of my good friends is a doctor and her BC was very aggressive...she was the one that told me to breathe and think all of it through..you do have time. BUT that being said i KNOW how you feel about wanting it out ASAP. I was that way too. Most of all I wish you the best in whatever you decide.
Posts.Title: Biopy yesterday- today I am a cancer patient!! jeanwash msphil

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2008 11:29AM bettysgirl wrote: lynette- so sorry you had trouble with the FEC. I was very fortunate in that i was nauseated but not so bad that i couldn't function. The emend really helps but i did have other back ups too. I think the other post says it all. Prevent--take the meds before you get to feeling that way. Sorry also about the constipation..that seems to come with it for some. Mine tends to run the other way. At least now you know how better to manage things the next go round. Take care of yourself and get all the rest you need. Glad you are feeling better.
Posts.Title: My first FEC.... Lynette bettysgirl

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2009 04:28AM bettysgirl wrote: i also had FEC and taxotere. Fec was a cake walk compared to the taxotere. My hands never peeled but did look chemically burned after the first taxotere. I was also out of commission for almost a week. VERY sick. Had to go back for fluids and steroid two days in a row. Pain was horrible and I slept for almost the whole first week. BUT my onco listened to all I described and once I showed him my hands he told me it was an indication that the dosage was too strong and we lessened the dosage for the second tax. It worked for me. It didn't make taxotere easier but did prevent the previous problems. We had also discussed that abraxane woul be the next move if i continued to have problems. It is a wicked drug. Lots of people react to it. Onco told me it is the preservative that they are reacting to and that abraxane has a preservative that is more of a human protien and that is why they don't react to it. I know how frustrating it is. While I was having all my problems my onco was out of town. I told the nurse he was going to have to give me a good reason to come back and do Taxotere again. Thankfully when I went back he sat and listened to me for a long time, (almost 30 mins) and we lowered the dosage. So sorry you had this experience. Thankfully we all survived it.
Posts.Title: Taxotere - BEWARE!! Beach Beach

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2008 02:37AM bettysgirl wrote: you have to do what is right for you. I chose bi-lat w/no recon in July. i actaully found women here and talked to those that had done bi-lats, single mast. and some with recon/ some not. Several of the women here (laid back south) told me they found it liberating to be able to dress creatively and not have to worry about prosthesis in the heat...one had single mast and has trouble keeping the girls straight...I had very large dense breasts and don't miss the almost 8 lbs i lost. I guess there are days when i go to the closet and find pretty shirts i cannot wear anymore due to the neckline that i get frustrated....(more about them being fairly new) but I won't have a tumor sneak up in the non cancer side like the cancer side did and I won't sit around wondering how long it would have taken for all those fibrocystic cysts to change. It was right for me. There are down sides...but once again keep seeking advice, read lots and know all about it then make your decision. Good luck
Posts.Title: Please tell me I'm not crazy Jasminn bettysgirl

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2009 08:03PM bettysgirl wrote: i am sorry for your diagnosis and at such a bad time of year for it. You have come to the best place in the world for information, support and to make some great friends. The beginning is indeed the worst time and once you know more you will move forward a step at a time with great help from those here and from those around you. Know that all of us are pulling for you and rooting you on.
Posts.Title: Just diadnosed and petrified SPoole Frankie_

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2009 09:02PM bettysgirl wrote: it is a difficult thing to do. All of us have to come to a time where we are able to face what has happene to us and I think before you can move forward you have to do this. You may want someone with you or maybe not. Before you can grieve (and yes you do grieve) you must face this fear head on. You may have to talk to a counselor to help you through this. It also may help if you know someone who has had surgery that will show you theirs first. I had a friend to that for me to know what to expect. It helps to know you aren't the only one that looks like you look. Hang in there and I will be pulling for ya!
Posts.Title: Scared To Look At My Surgical Site ibjennifer125 pshelton

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2009 10:06PM bettysgirl wrote: i'm sorry you are having to go through this. I can't imagine being told it was benign then reversed. You do need to take someone with you to be a second set of ears and hear what you don't. (there will be stuff you just don't hear)  The beginning IS the worst part because there is so much unknown and so much waiting. I don't know how things will be for you but once I went back for the actual DX things moved quickly with lots of other tests. I know that it is a difficult thing to swallow and it is a scary time for you. For me once we were "doing" something I felt a little better but those first two weeks were pure agony. DO get a copy of the path results so you can see it for yourself AND research it. Come here to question, rant or rave or scream if you'd like and know that while we always hate to see a new member there is lots of love and support here.
Posts.Title: recieved 2 different diagnoses today... Klawless9 swest

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2009 09:20AM bettysgirl wrote: i had bi-lat last July- I have not regretted doing the bi-lat with no recon. There are times when clothes don't fit good and you get frustrated but i have not worn any prothesis since surgery...i take that back i tried it once, was VERY uncomfortable with it,,,felt so fake and didn't do it again. I wear layered shirts to work, then sometime just don't worry about it at all...My tummy got bigger once to boobs were gone ....(or did i just notice it more LOL) but all in all i was also glad to take the time to fight the beast and not go through long recovery of recon. I was glad to be able to check out breastfree also and know that there are a lot of us who are happy in our skin and able to adjust to what we have been given.
Posts.Title: thank you for giving me a choice seltzer wallycat

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2009 12:28AM bettysgirl wrote: hope your baby s feeling better. As a kitty lover and one who has been through the pain of losing one that has been right there for you I know the fears when they get sick. I hope that she is better soon. HUGS to you.
Posts.Title: So Sad... not about cancer LittleFlower LittleFlower

Posts.Content: May 8, 2009 11:41PM - edited May 8, 2009 11:43PM by bettysgirl I was able to take a shower on day two. I was told to put watertight bandaids over the drain exit sites and to dry them well after and apply antibiotic ointment on them. I "walked" my arms up the sides of the shower because the hot water helped loosen things up for me. I used a lanyard to hold the drains up. I had no problem brushing my teeth or my hair but the hair was much more difficult. Do what you tolerate. You have to relearn how to do some things and some bathroom duties were difficult (sorry if it's TMI) It passes soon enough and you are on your way. I agree make a list and ask your doctor as ALL of them have different preferences. You will be fine and I wish you all the best. PS i hear from my path work by the Monday after my surgery on a Wed.
Posts.Title: Questions about After Bilateral Mastectomy hlya lifegoeson

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 01:23AM bettysgirl wrote: i thought i had cruised past the nail problem thing and then about 3-4 wks post chemo nails and toenails all started to lift. Like mentioned above I tried to keep things clean but there was no pain involved. Fingernails were a little tender when i tried to use them so i kept them trimmed really close. In the end I lost all fingernails and toenails. Fingernails have recovered and are beginning to grow. Most of the toenails are back with the exception of the two big toenails that are much slower growing for some reason. It is aggravating but they will come back. I bought some Sally Hanson formula to help with the fingernail ridges and thinness..it has made a huge difference.

You will get through these days if you gather a good support group of friends and come here when you have questions. Soon you will be posting all kinds of encouraging words to to others that are new to the experience and you will be thriving and surviving! HUGS to you!!

Posts.Title: About to Lose it.... dmd2420 sheila888

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2009 04:08PM bettysgirl wrote: swest gave you a great answer. I always tended to see more accumulation of fluid after any activity. Especially after a shower. Some days the fluid will be less some days more. Just make sure to "milk" the drains a couple of times a day. Squeezing all the air out of the bulbs before reconnecting them helps the suction keep working. Like she said with 6 i am sure some will not put out as much as others. I wish your mom a speedy recovery also. She is blessed to have you to help her.

This last chemo or me has been awful and i sooo want to quit but it is the loving people (real people) around me that rally me in the times i want to curl up and die. You are a HERO in my book!!!!
Posts.Title: Christina Applegate and radiation tomatojuice deadlanguages

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 11:29PM bettysgirl wrote: it looks like all of us have undergone periods of great stress! I know that the past two years prior to my dx was the WORST two of our life. I tend to internalize stress so there's that. My coping abilities changed alot after my mom died and i was the executor for my dad's estate. My daughter had two children in two years (unwed) we have had a lot of other things on our plate... while i am not sure we can pin the blame on stress i sure believe it can contribute to  alot of other medical issues..maybe it is a catalyst for growth but i had on onco nurse tell me that stress manaagement was KEY while going through treatment...HAH treatment IS stress...we just have to deal with what we are given and we can't change it. I wish i could blame it on stress but im not sure i can.

Posts.Title: Teenager worried o.o LunaMoon barbe1958

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2009 10:53PM bettysgirl wrote: im also sorry you joined the club nobody wants to be a part of. I will agree that this is a true roller coaster ride and sometimes you want to scream at the top of your lungs to get off. we are here to be a sounding board for you and you are not bringing us down. We all go through anger and questions and try to make sense of a disease that is NO respector of persons. Young and old,   we are all women who have heard those words and all wanted so badly to be able to have never heard them at all. We can be here to listen and to encourage you. I don't think any of us know why we were the "chosen ones". I too have heard the "you are so strong"..but i also wasn't given a choice. I was given a diagnosis and like it or not i had to do something about it.I hope you can find a good friend to talk to, maybe even another survivor. I have some great friends who have helped me beause they have been there too. BUT I have some great ladies i am priveledged to call friends that i made here. They have been here with me from the beginning and I love them all dearly. My hope is that you find a support like that and i wish you all the best as you heal from surgeries. Lisa/BG
Posts.Title: Not really understanding why I have BC 4lumps Hattie

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2009 02:57AM bettysgirl wrote: I don't know how my onco will weigh in on this. I see him again next week for follow up since starting the tamoxifen...My biggest thing is that all the people that have been supporting us in prayer and close friends keep asking how soon he is going to scan to give me an all clear....While i want to hear those words, after almost a solid year of appointments and treatments and travel, I can say that it does not bother me to have to not think about that right now. We are planning a vacation in June that I am looking forward to and it will fall right at my cancerversary...Maybe I will change that thought process but I HATE the waiting that goes with those tests.
Posts.Title: What's your opinion on post-treatment tests staceyshusband bettysgirl

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 03:39AM bettysgirl wrote: i dont remember how long it took two yrs ago but when i had the biopsy this yr he told me it didn't feel good that he suggested i prepare for the worst. ( he told me that 2 ys ago and it was B9.) Anyway i got the call the very next day by lunch that it was a malignancy. I didn't have family history either. Just a history of fibrocystic disease. They scheduled me quickly for further testing. I wish you the best.
Posts.Title: Biopsy mommycjk leaf

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2012 03:14PM bettysgirl wrote: I had FEC (3) and taxotere (3) in 2008. It is NOT as bad as you expect but i will ditto what i read before, i don't wish it on anyone but once you have to have it, it is something you can tolerate. I had very little nausea, just a few days after the first treatment. They gave me lots of meds and Emend is great. I also had neulasta shots. I began with constipation but mostly had diarreah. Buy things to prepare for both. I was out of work for about 3-4 days after each FEC treatment and a little longer after each taxotere. My hair fell out in about 15 days also. I wore a wig to work and scarves or nothing at home. I had thrush after each treatment that was worse after taxotere. With taxotere everything tasted like cardboard..you have to seek things that taste good. Lots of water and or gatorade is highly suggested. I had a port and was glad i did. Never had any trouble with it. I nursed my nails during chemo and treated them with strengthening polish and thought i had done real well, no discoloration, no blackness and all of a sudden one day one fell off, quickly followed by the rest and soon to follow were the toenails.. My hair started growing back during the taxotere and was a thin covering of down by the time i finished 6 wks of rads. When it came in it did come in curly but i lost my chemo curls quick. There were some days when i wondered how chemo could go so smoothly and some days (like after the first taxotere) that i wondered how i was gonna do this.. You take a day at a time, pray a lot and I was a part of a group of girls on here that all had chemo in Sept of 08. Find a group and hopefully you will bond like we did. It does help because you all can compare stories. Chemo is like birth stories..sometimes they grow worse with time or you forget the pain...Either way it helps to have supportive people around you that know what you are dealing with. I wish you all the best. You CAN do it!!
Posts.Title: Chemo advice from veterans? Please post!!!! ElleBee pamelahope

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2009 10:45AM bettysgirl wrote: so sorry you had this reaction. I had the taxotere. It is one tough drug. There were a few girls in my group that did react but not quite as bad as you desrcibe. They would stop the drip, give oxygen and benadryl and wait before starting the drip again. We did see one that had a severe reaction on her second infusion and they were going to have to try something else. The first infusion i had i was sooo sick and out of things for about a week. My hands looked like they had been chemically burned. I had to go back two days for fluids and steroids. We had to lower the dosage and i did better. But at that time the onco told me that it is the preservative in the taxotere that most people are reacting to. Abraxane is a kind of sister drug to taxotere but uses a human protein for the preservative. You may have to change to that or another drug all together. I hope that you are feeling much better and that your onco figures out the best plan for you. Take care BG
Posts.Title: Taxotere reaction lissak LRM216

Posts.Title: Fear of sentinal node biopsy warren3 2Hands4me

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2008 09:59AM bettysgirl wrote: All of us here have been where you are now. It is a big step to take but must be done. You have to do this for yourself but also for those who love you and need you to be there for them. We will be praying for your surgery and a quick recovery to follow. As the other girls have said, take it a step at a time. You WILL be able to do this. Sommhow we summon the courage to forge ahead even when the mind tells us we can't. All surgery is scary and this one brings up so many emotions..let yourself cry when you need to then move on to do what you have to do. We will be here to listen when you want to rant, rave and cry. Best Wishes to you
Posts.Title: Bilat Mast, Chemo, Rad HopeForBest HopeForBest

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 05:16PM bettysgirl wrote: i would have to say it does since it seems to be a given in node positive cancers... As far as the mush brain i am on fec right now also and it was worse the first treatment than this time although there are times where i just feel like i am in a fog and know that i am not as sharp as i should be. I do beleive there is a chemo brain effect...although i think it is also a combo of fatigue, stress and the illness itself combined with all the drugs we take for SE's. Hope you feel clear again soon.
Posts.Title: Does chemo zap cancer in nodes... Lynette Maryiz

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2009 10:40PM bettysgirl wrote: sorry you had to come here but you will find great support here just like we did in the beginning. The initial days and weeks right after you are diagnosed are the worst. Once I got into the active treatment phase and had a plan mapped out it eased the worry some as i was finally soing something. Don't look too far down the road take it in a little at a time and know that there are women here who can answer your questions, listen to your rants and cheer you on a bad day. While all of us wishes we didn't have to be here it is a WONDERFUL site for support and you will meet many new SUPER cyber friends. Best wishes to you Lisa/Bettysgirl
